name: Etchmiadzin Cathedral
description: Etchmiadzin Cathedral is the spiritual center of the Armenian Apostolic Church, founded by Gregory the Illuminator at the beginning of the 4th century. It is one of the oldest Christian churches in the world and is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List.

name: Surb Zoravor Astvatsatsin
description: Surb Zoravor Astvatsatsin was founded in the 9th century, destroyed by the earthquake of 1679 and rebuilt in 1693–1694. It is one of the oldest surviving churches in Yerevan and a symbol of spiritual revival.

name: Geghard Monastery
description: Geghard Monastery, founded in the 4th century, is partly carved out of rock. It became famous for housing the spear that wounded Christ on the Cross. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Tatev Monastery
description: Tatev Monastery was founded in the 9th century and served as an important educational and spiritual center, housing one of the oldest universities of the Middle Ages in Armenia.

name: Khor Virap Monastery
description: Khor Virap is one of the most visited pilgrimage sites in Armenia. It is where Gregory the Illuminator was imprisoned for 13 years before converting King Tiridates III to Christianity in 301.

name: Noravank Monastery
description: Noravank, founded in the 12th century, is renowned for its dramatic setting in a narrow gorge and its unique two-story Surb Astvatsatsin church built by Momik the architect.

name: Sanahin Monastery
description: Sanahin Monastery, founded in the 10th century, was a major center of learning and culture. Today it is partially preserved and included in the UNESCO World Heritage List together with Haghpat.

name: Haghpat Monastery
description: Haghpat Monastery, dating back to the 10th century, is one of the most outstanding examples of medieval Armenian architecture. It was a major religious, cultural, and educational center.

name: Amberd Church (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The church of Surb Astvatsatsin at Amberd fortress was built in the 11th century by the Pahlavuni princes. It is partly in ruins but remains an important historical monument.

name: Zvartnots Cathedral
description: Zvartnots Cathedral, built in the 7th century under Catholicos Nerses III, was one of the most magnificent churches of early medieval Armenia. Destroyed by an earthquake in the 10th century, its ruins are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Holy Transfiguration Cathedral (Moscow)
description: The Holy Transfiguration Cathedral, consecrated in 2013, is the main church of the Armenian Apostolic Church in Russia and the spiritual center of the community.

name: St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral (New York)
description: St. Vartan Cathedral is the main Armenian church in New York, consecrated in 1968. It serves as the center of the Armenian Apostolic Church in the USA.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church (Glendale)
description: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church in Glendale is one of the largest Armenian churches in California and the spiritual center of the local community.

name: Saint Catherine's Armenian Church
description: Saint Catherine's Armenian Church, designed by Yury Felten and built in 1771–1776, was consecrated on February 18, 1780, by Archbishop Joseph (Argutinsky) in the presence of Prince Potemkin. It is one of the oldest Armenian churches in Russia and has long served as a spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community.

name: Church of the Resurrection (Surb Harutyun)
description: The Church of the Resurrection (Surb Harutyun) in Rostov-on-Don, consecrated in 2011, was built in the traditional style of Armenian church architecture.

name: Holy Cross Church (Surb Khach)
description: Holy Cross Church (Surb Khach) in Nakhichevan-on-Don was built in 1786–1792. After being closed during the Soviet era, it was reopened in 2000.

name: Church of the Ascension
description: The Church of the Ascension in Chaltyr was founded in 1860. It has been functioning since 1944 and serves as the spiritual center of the Armenians in the region.

name: Saint Hripsime Church
description: Saint Hripsime Church is an Armenian Apostolic church in Astrakhan, serving as a functioning temple and the spiritual center of the local Armenian community.

name: Saint George Church (Surb Gevorg)
description: Saint George Church (Surb Gevorg) is an Armenian Apostolic church in Cherkessk, a functioning temple and spiritual center of the Armenian community in the city.

name: Saint Gevorg Church
description: Saint Gevorg Church in Volgograd is an active Armenian church, uniting the Armenian community of the city.

name: Saint Hovhannes Church (Surb Hovhannes)
description: Saint Hovhannes Church (Surb Hovhannes) is an Armenian Apostolic church in Maykop, serving as a spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community in the region.

name: Surb Karapet Church
description: Surb Karapet Church in Yekaterinburg is an active Armenian church, built at the end of the 20th century, bringing together the Armenian community of the Urals.

name: Church of Saint Sarkis
description: The Church of Saint Sarkis in Adler was built in 1997–1998. The temple is designed in traditional Armenian architectural style and serves as a spiritual center of the Armenian diaspora of the city.

name: Church of Saint Mariam Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Saint Mariam Astvatsatsin is an Armenian Apostolic church in Krasnodar. It is an active temple serving as a spiritual and cultural center for Armenians of Kuban.

name: Church of Surb Vardan
description: The Church of Surb Vardan in Kislovodsk is an Armenian Apostolic church, an active temple founded in the early 21st century.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Pyatigorsk is an active Armenian temple built with the support of the local community.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg
description: The Church of Surb Gevorg (Saint George) in Sultan-Saly was founded in 1795 and rebuilt in 1867. It is one of the oldest Armenian temples in the Don region. During World War II the building was damaged and partially destroyed. Today the church remains in ruins and requires restoration, but it is still regarded as an important monument of Armenian heritage in Russia.

name: Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator in Novorossiysk was built between 2001 and 2008. Designed by architect Levon Avalyan, the temple is clad in pink tuff brought from Armenia.

name: Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator in Vladimir is an Armenian Apostolic church consecrated in 2017. It was built with the support of the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach)
description: The Church of the Holy Cross (Surb Khach) in Samara was built between 1998 and 2003 and consecrated in 2003. It serves as an active parish and the spiritual center of the Armenian community in the Volga region.

name: Church of St. Grigoris
description: The Church of St. Grigoris in Nyugdi was built in 1916. It remains an important religious center for the Armenian community of the region.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Krasnoyarsk is the first Armenian church built east of the Urals. Constructed in the late 1990s, it was consecrated in 2003 and unites the Armenian community of Siberia.

name: Church of Surb Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Novosibirsk is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as an active parish and cultural center for the local Armenian community.

name: Church of Christ the Savior
description: The Church of Christ the Savior in Kirov is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as a spiritual hub for the Armenian community of the region.

name: Church of Surb Astvatsatsin
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin in Saratov is an Armenian Apostolic church, serving as an active parish and spiritual center for Armenians of the Volga region.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Ulyanovsk was consecrated in 2023. A modern Armenian Apostolic church built with the support of the local community.

name: Church of Surb Stepanos
description: The Church of Surb Stepanos in Kaliningrad is an Armenian Apostolic church and a spiritual center for the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of Surb Harutyun
description: The Church of Surb Harutyun in Moscow was founded in 1815 by the Lazarev brothers. It was later closed, but returned to the community in 1956. Today it functions as an active parish and a historical cultural center.

name: Church of Surb Harutyun
description: The Church of Surb Harutyun in Tver is an active Armenian Apostolic church and a community center for Armenians of the city.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg
description: The Church of Surb Gevorg in Yaroslavl is the first Armenian church in the region, consecrated in 2017.

name: Church of Surb Sargis
description: The Church of Surb Sargis in Voronezh is an active parish of the Armenian Apostolic Church, built with Armenian tuff and decorated with khachkars. Architect: Gevorg Shirvanyan.

name: Church of Surb Amenaprkich (All-Savior)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Amenaprkich in Nizhny Novgorod was built between 2008–2014 and consecrated on May 25, 2014. Constructed from Armenian tuff, it features khachkars and a cultural center.

name: Church of Surb Ripsime
description: The Church of Surb Ripsime in Barnaul was built between 2001–2008, consecrated by Catholicos Karekin II in October 2008. Built in traditional Armenian style with red brick, with a khachkar nearby.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Sosnovka was registered in May 2008 and consecrated on August 24, 2008. The opening was attended by over 400 Armenians and representatives of other faith communities.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Vladikavkaz was built in 1868. It is a cultural heritage monument, with a khachkar in the yard dedicated to the memory of the Armenian Genocide victims.

name: Church of Surb Amenaprkich (All-Savior)
description: The Church of Surb Amenaprkich in Derbent was built in 1870–1871, with a bell tower added in 1888. Recognized as an architectural monument in 1975, services resumed in 2009.

name: Monastery of Surb Khach
description: The Monastery of Surb Khach (Holy Cross) was founded in 1358. The complex includes Surb Nshan Church, a gavit, refectory, cells, and khachkars. Closed in 1925, restored from the 1980s, services resumed in 1994.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: Built at the initiative of the Armenian community of Dnipro, the church was founded in 2003, with active construction beginning in 2010 using peach-colored tuff imported from Armenia. The consecration of the altar and domes took place in 2017, and the church was solemnly consecrated on March 17, 2018, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The church hosts a Sunday school and is considered the largest Armenian church in Eastern Europe, serving as a major cultural and religious center.

name: Armenian Cathedral of the Assumption of the Holy Virgin
description: The Armenian Cathedral of the Assumption in Lviv is one of the city’s oldest landmarks. Built between 1363 and 1370 to the design of architect Doring, the church combines Armenian, Romanesque-Gothic, and Galician architectural elements and is included on the UNESCO World Heritage List. The complex includes the belfry (1571), archbishop’s palace, Armenian bank, Benedictine convent, St. Christopher’s column (1726), and southern arcade (1437). The interior features frescoes by Jan Henryk Rosen with Armenian motifs.

name: Holy Resurrection Church (Surb Harutyun)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of Surb Harutyun in Kharkiv was founded on July 1, 2000, and consecrated on August 24, 2004, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The project was designed by Pavlo Chechelnytskyi, chief architect of Kharkiv. Built with stone imported from Armenia, the interior is decorated in traditional Armenian style.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles Peter and Paul
description: An Armenian Catholic church built for the Armenian community of Chernivtsi, designed by architect Josef Hlávka. Construction took place between 1869 and October 1875, and it was consecrated on October 9, 1875. The architecture blends Romanesque, Gothic, and Ukrainian Baroque styles. Known for its acoustics and organ, since 1986 it has served as the Organ Hall of the Chernivtsi Philharmonic. Closed during Soviet times, it was later restored and returned to the faithful.

name: Church of the Annunciation of the Holy Virgin
description: The Church of the Annunciation in Ivano-Frankivsk (historically Stanislaviv) was built by the Armenian community in the mid-17th century and became a spiritual center for the local Armenian diaspora. The building combines Baroque and Renaissance elements, with frescoes and icons dating to the 17th–18th centuries. The church was renovated in the 19th century, but suffered damage and losses during World War II and Soviet times. Religious life was restored in the 1990s, with cultural initiatives revived in the 2000s. Today, it remains a major spiritual and cultural center of Armenians in Galicia.

name: Armenian Apostolic Church of Odessa
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church in Odessa is located in the Gagarin Plateau district. It serves as the spiritual center of the Armenian community, hosting liturgies, baptisms, and weddings. The modern building, designed in Armenian architectural style, harmonizes with the Black Sea coastal landscape.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The first Armenian church complex in Belarus — St. Gregory the Illuminator Church — was consecrated on May 18, 2025, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. Construction lasted from August 2022 to April 2025, designed by Armenian architect Samvel Makhyan. Built with volcanic tuff and travertine from Armenia, the church has become the spiritual and cultural center of the Armenian community in Belarus.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Tallinn)
description:
The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Tallinn is an Armenian Apostolic Church. The building was originally a Lutheran church of St. John, dating back to the 13th century. The Armenian community received it in 1993 and restored it by the early 2000s. The consecration and installation of khachkars were performed with the participation of Armenian bishops.

Today it functions as an active church and the spiritual center of the Armenian community of Estonia, combining Armenian traditions with the historic fabric of Tallinn.

name: Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator (Riga)
description: The Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in Riga is the first Armenian Apostolic church in the Baltic and Scandinavian countries. Its foundation stone was laid on December 17, 1997. Designed by Hakob Babakhanyan, it was clad in travertine imported from Iran. It was consecrated on June 30, 2011, by Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II. The church also hosts a Sunday school named after Ghazaros Aghayan, and a khachkar made of Armenian tuff stands in the courtyard. Since 2005, the parish priest has been Fr. Khosrov Stepanyan (Ter-Khosrov). The church can hold around 100 worshippers.

name: Church of St. Vardan
description: The Church of St. Vardan in Vilnius was founded by the Armenian community of Lithuania. The parish was established in 1994, and the church was opened in 2006. It serves as the main spiritual and cultural center for Armenians in Lithuania.

name: Church of Surb Gevorg (St. George)
description:
The Church of Surb Gevorg in Vladivostok is one of the main spiritual centers of the Armenian community of Primorye. Armenians settled in the region at the end of the 19th century, and in 1906 the city council allocated land for a church and community house. By 1915, a prayer house was operating, and services continued until 1942, even under Soviet restrictions.

After WWII, the building fell into disrepair, and by the 1990s only ruins remained. Plans to demolish it were stopped by the Armenian community. In the early 2000s, a new church was built on the same site, with part of the old wall preserved as a monument.

The new church, built of red brick in traditional Armenian style, was consecrated in 2007. Today it is a cultural and spiritual symbol for Armenians in Vladivostok and the Russian Far East.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin) in Chisinau is one of the oldest Armenian churches in Bessarabia. Built in 1803–1804 on the site of a destroyed Moldovan church, its architecture includes an elongated nave, a two-tiered bell tower, and a three-arched portico. During Soviet times, it was used as a warehouse, but in 1992 it was returned to the Armenian community, and services resumed on June 19, 1993.

name: Church of Surb Karapet
description: The Church of Surb Karapet in Almaty is the first Armenian Apostolic parish in Kazakhstan. It was opened on October 7, 2006, with the support of the 'Nairi' Association of Armenian Cultural Centers. It was consecrated by Bishop Ezras Nersisyan. The parish hosts a Sunday school and cultural programs.

name: Church of St. Philip (Surb Pilipos)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Philip in Tashkent was founded by the Armenian community in 1993. After its closure during Soviet times, it was returned to the faithful following Uzbekistan's independence. The consecration and first liturgy were held in 1995. The church was officially registered on January 12, 2007, during the tenure of Fr. Gevorg Vardanyan. Today it is led by Fr. Garnik Loretsyan and serves as the center of the Armenian community in Tashkent.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
description: The Church of Surb Astvatsatsin (Holy Mother of God) in Samarkand was built in 1903 with funds from the local Armenian community, with Fr. Ruben Bekgulyants as its first pastor. It was closed in 1939 during the Soviet period. After Uzbekistan's independence, it was restored and re-consecrated in 1995 with the participation of Archbishop Nerses Pozapalyan. Today it serves as the cultural and spiritual center of Armenians in Samarkand.

name: Church of Surb Karapet
description:
The Church of Surb Karapet in Yakutsk is the northernmost Armenian church in the world. Its foundation was laid in 2011, and it was consecrated in 2012. The church is 27 meters high, with materials such as stone, glass, and wood brought from Armenia. The exterior is clad in natural tuff.

The Armenian community of Yakutia has existed since the late 19th century. Despite the harsh climate and remoteness of the region, Armenians preserved their faith and traditions. Today, the church unites Armenians of Yakutia and neighboring regions, serving as a major cultural and spiritual center.

name: Armenian Apostolic Church
description: A multifunctional Armenian spiritual and cultural complex in Izhevsk. It includes a church, a memorial to the victims of the Armenian Genocide, and a miniature of Mount Ararat with a pond shaped like Lake Sevan and fountains symbolizing the regions of Armenia. Built with support from the Armenian community of Udmurtia, it serves about 5,000 Armenians (around 3,000 in Izhevsk). The complex houses a national school and a library and is open to everyone. Today the church holds regular liturgies and religious rites and is the spiritual center of the region’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Resurrection
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Resurrection in old Armanitola, Dhaka, is one of the city’s oldest Christian structures. Built in 1781 on the site of a former wooden chapel at the cemetery, it was consecrated by Bishop Yeprem. The church preserves original Armenian architectural features with four arched doors, 27 windows, and wooden seating for about one hundred worshipers. Around it lies an Armenian cemetery with many granite tombstones. Today there is no permanent parish: services are held twice a year by an archbishop from Australia.

name: Church of St. Nazareth (Surb Nazareth)
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Nazareth is one of Kolkata’s oldest Christian sanctuaries. Founded around 1708, rebuilt in 1724, and the current building dates to 1764. The interiors feature marble, frescoes, and paintings by A. E. Harris; the altar bears crosses, the Gospel, and candlesticks. The grounds include an Armenian cemetery with historic tombstones. Today the church remains a spiritual and cultural center for the city’s Armenian community.

name: Church of the Holy Mother of God (Surb Astvatsatsin)
address: Chennai, Armenian Street, George Town, Tamil Nadu, India
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Mother of God in Chennai is one of the oldest on the Indian subcontinent. Built in 1712 and reconstructed in 1772, it is famed for its belfry with six bells, the largest weighing up to 150 kg, rung every Sunday at 9:30 a.m. Around the church lie about 350 Armenian graves, including that of Harutyun Shmavonyan, publisher of the first Armenian periodical, Azdarar. The church functions as a historical and cultural landmark and is open daily; services are held rarely.

name: Church of St. John
description: The Church of St. John in Chinsurah was built in 1697 (some sources say 1695) and dedicated to St. John the Baptist. It is the second-oldest Christian church in Bengal and the oldest Armenian church in India. Each year on January 13–14, a feast is celebrated in honor of St. John the Baptist, when relics are brought from the Armenian church in Nazareth (about 65 km away). Nearby is the family cemetery of the Melik-Beglaryan princes. The Armenian community began forming here in 1645, after the Dutch established the colony in 1625; by the late 19th century it was quite sizable. On March 1, 2007, Catholicos of All Armenians Karekin II visited the church.

name: Church of St. John the Baptist
address: 66 Bo Aung Kyaw Street, Yangon, Myanmar
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. John the Baptist in Yangon is the country’s oldest and only active Armenian church. Built in 1862 and consecrated in 1863, it stands on land granted to the Armenian community by the King of Burma. The Armenian presence dates to the 17th century. Today only about 10–20 Armenian families remain; services are held regularly, often by a visiting priest.

name: St. Gregory the Illuminator Church
description: The Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator in the Emirate of Sharjah is the principal spiritual center of the Armenian Apostolic Church in the UAE. Built in 1980 with the blessing of Catholicos Vazgen I and through the efforts of the Gulf Armenian community, it was consecrated by Archbishop Shaghe Aidemiryan. The complex, executed in traditional Armenian style with modern elements, includes the church, parish rooms, and a cultural hall. Today it serves Armenians across the UAE and neighboring countries.

name: Armenian Church in Payadzhuk
address: Payadzhuk village, Salmas County, West Azerbaijan, Iran
description: The church in Payadzhuk is almost completely ruined; only foundation traces remain. Cemeteries and the grave of Archimandrite Yeghiazar were also destroyed; khachkars were overturned and broken, and tombstones looted, especially after 2011. The village also housed the birthplace of the Armenian writer Raffi (Hakob Melik-Hakobyan, 1835), the remnants of which have likewise vanished.

name: Armenian Church of St. John in Sarna
address: Sarna village, Salmas County, West Azerbaijan, Iran
description: The Armenian Church of St. John in Sarna suffered extensive illicit excavations. Huge pits were dug inside the building and near the altar, damaging the walls. The destruction is linked to widespread treasure-hunting; both Christian and Muslim graves were disturbed.

name: Armenian Cemeteries in Salmas County
description: Armenian cemeteries at churches and separate clergy burials in Salmas County were destroyed: stones overturned, tombs dug up, khachkars disappeared. This wave of looting was especially intense after 2011.
